instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a 5.20v
threads.message:
The LB is pretty much new and super Clean and here what i got so far:

USB-C PM = 5.20V

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.26V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> = 12.26V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_GPU</SIGNAL> = 12.26V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_OTH5V</SIGNAL> = 12.26V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_3V3G3H_T</SIGNAL> = 12.26V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_3V3G3HRTC_X</SIGNAL> = 12.26

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_T</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_X</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> = 0V - Diode Mode =  0.402
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S3</SIGNAL> = 0V - Diode Mode = 0.251

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a 5.20v
threads.message: Did you try T2 firmware recover yet?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a 5.20v
threads.message:
Did you follow all the steps correctly???
Be aware, only one USB-C port is dedicated for recovery.
Be sure to get proper USB/Thunderbolt cable to connect both MacBooks...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a 5.20v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a 5.20v
threads.message:
After i tried a couple times, I got an error message:

The OS cannot be restored on this device.
Gave up waiting for the device transition from REstore OS state to BootedOS state.
[com.apple.MobileDevice.Mobile.Restore - 0xFA5 (4005)]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a 5.20v
threads.message:
Everything works.
When you get that message, you just need update the OS and try it again.
Problem Solved.

Thank you
